Course Map

WHAT 62 MILES OF HASTINGS ACTUALLY LOOKS LIKE

Hover over the profile to see where the climbs, chaos, and "why did I sign up for this" moments actually are.

Mile 1.5
Three Sisters

Three consecutive punchy climbs immediately after leaving pavement. Primary selection point. If you're not with the lead group here, you won't bridge.

The Selection PointFirst real test of the day
Mile 18
Sager Road

Unmaintained seasonal two-track with sand ruts, mud holes, and baby-head rocks. This is the signature section that defines Barry-Roubaix.

The Signature Suffering100-mile version adds 'Big Papa' with more sand, more climbing, and two unavoidable mud puddles
Mile 25
The Wall

0.2-mile climb averaging 11% with a false summit and a 'fun little final pitch.' Many athletes walk portions.

The Walk ZoneComes late enough to expose fatigue but early enough to not be the final climb
Course Breakdown: Suffering zones are based on race reports, Strava segments, and course analysis. Terrain details reflect typical conditions—weather can dramatically change difficulty.
Elevation + route courtesy of RideWithGPS. Suffering courtesy of you.

Race Guide

BARRY-ROUBAIX
OVERVIEW & TRAINING GUIDE

World's Largest Gravel Race

This page is your briefing: what the race actually is, how it breaks riders, and how to show up with a body and brain that can survive 62 miles of punchy, technical, unpredictable. michigan doesn't do sustained climbs—it does 50+ rollers that hit you constantly. sager road defines the race's character..

Quick Facts

Race Vitals

The numbers that matter. Everything else is commentary.

LocationHastings, Michigan (Barry County)
Date2026: April 18
Distance62 miles
Elevation Gain~4,000 ft
TerrainSeasonal two-track roads, sand ruts, mud holes, baby-head rocks, punchy rollers, pavement sections
Field Size5,500+ riders from 48 states and 9 countries
Start Time62-mile: 10:00 AM, 36-mile: 9:00 AM, 18-mile: 10:15 AM, 100-mile: 7:00 AM
RegistrationOpens November 15 annually. Sells out in 24 hours. Cost: $79-119 depending on distance
Prize Purse$40,000+ distributed
Aid StationsFour aid stations for 62-mile, five for 100-mile. Well-stocked with water, snacks, neutral support.
Cut-off Time100-mile has cutoffs: Mile 41 by 11:30 AM, Mile 62 by 1:15 PM, Mile 88 by 4:00 PM (~10 mph minimum)

You Should Race This If:

You want the world's largest gravel race experience, you can handle technical terrain and unpredictable weather, and you're ready to commit to registration within 24 hours of opening.

Get a Training Plan →

Skip This If:

You need guaranteed good weather, you can't handle technical two-track roads, or you're looking for smooth, fast gravel without surprises.

Facts And History

Barry-Roubaix is what happens when ambition meets reality

Started as a local gravel race in Hastings, Michigan. Grew to become the world's largest gravel race with 5,500+ riders from 48 states and 9 countries.

The Experience

You roll out of Hastings wedged into a nervous pack of riders, half of whom are over-biked and under-trained. The first hour feels almost polite. Then the field hits the first challenging sections and you start seeing people on the side of the road wrestling with mechanicals and broken spirits.

The middle third is pure accounting: calories, bottles, chain lube, and bad decisions. The race doesn't "start" so much as it quietly removes options until you're either riding alone into a crosswind, clinging to a group that's too strong, or sitting in a folding chair at a checkpoint trying to decide if you're the kind of person who goes back out into the dark.

2009
Inaugural race with local field
2017
39°F with freezing rain, 41.9% DNF rate
2022
35°F with 19°F wind chill, 30 mph gusts, 43.1% DNF rate
2025
Perfect 58°F conditions, multiple course records broken, 21.1% DNF rate
2026
17th edition, sells out in 24 hours

Barry-Roubaix Facts

◆ WHAT THE COURSE IS LIKE

COURSE BREAKDOWN

Gravel God Radar
Barry-Roubaix
Course Profile
Seven variables · 1–5 scale   |   Raw Course Score: 25 / 35
Length
4/5
Technicality
4/5
Elevation
2/5
Climate
5/5
Altitude
1/5
Adventure
4/5
Logistics
5/5
"You can train perfectly and still DNF if Michigan decides to throw 35°F windchill at you."

Length

Four distances span 18 to 100 miles. The 100-mile Psycho Killer with 7,000+ feet pushes into serious ultra territory. The flagship 62-mile Killer is substantial—long enough to hurt, technical enough to break you.

Technicality

Sager Road isn't gravel—it's a seasonal two-track with sand ruts, mud holes, and baby-head rocks that eat unprepared riders alive. Add Three Sisters at mile 1.5 and The Wall's 11% pitch, and you're looking at a course that demands real bike handling.

Elevation

4,000 feet for the 62-mile isn't extreme on paper, but Michigan doesn't do sustained climbs—it does punchy rollers that hit you 50+ times. More Belgian classic than Colorado mountain race. The cumulative fatigue sneaks up on you.

Climate

April in Michigan is chaos. Historical race temps range from 20°F to 81°F—a 61-degree swing. In bad years (2017, 2022), DNF rates hit 40%+. In good years, course records fall. You're gambling on weather no matter how well you train.

Altitude

Sea level. No altitude concerns. Your lungs work fine here—it's your legs and your ability to handle cold that get tested.

Adventure

The adventure here isn't Instagram vistas—it's the unpredictability. Weather roulette. Sager Road survival stories. The post-winter reunion with the cycling community. Every Barry-Roubaix is different, and that chaos IS the adventure.

Logistics

17 years of refinement shows. Gerald R. Ford International Airport is 26 miles away. 350 volunteers from 15+ organizations. Sells out in 24 hours because the operation is dialed. This is a professionally-run machine that happens to feel grassroots.

◆ BIASED OPINION

ELITE DESTINATION EVENT

Editorial Radar
Barry-Roubaix
Editorial Profile
Seven variables · 1–5 scale   |   Raw Editorial Score: 35 / 35
Prestige

5/5

5/5

5/5
Expenses
5/5
"World's largest gravel race. April Michigan weather. Sager Road. You'll remember this one."

Prestige

'World's Largest Gravel Race' isn't marketing—it's fact. 5,500+ riders from 48 states and 9 countries. On BikeExchange's bucket list. On GCN's Top Five. The race that proved gravel could scale without losing its soul.

Race Quality

350 volunteers from 15+ local organizations. Course marking is bulletproof. Four aid stations for the 62-mile, five for the 100. Wahoo partnership brings tech integration. Sells out in 24 hours because people know the product is dialed.

Experience

You will remember Barry-Roubaix. The year it snowed. The year you walked The Wall. The year you survived Sager Road when half the field didn't. The Blackrocks party afterward. The reunion with the cycling community after a long Midwest winter.

Community

Hastings doesn't just tolerate cyclists—it celebrates them. $1M+ economic impact. Blackrocks Brewery Street Party with bonfires and live music. 100% of beer proceeds go to Hastings Rotary. This isn't a race that happens despite the town; it's a race the town owns.

Field Depth

5,500 riders from 48 states and 9 countries creates genuine competitive depth at every level. The 100-mile Psycho Killer attracts serious ultra athletes. The 62-mile has a sharp end. Even the 36-mile sees real racing.

Value

$79-119 entry fees when other races charge $200-400. Youth ride FREE. You get a well-run event, multiple distance options, and the Blackrocks party for less than a mid-tier Wahoo KICKR session.

Expenses

This is the Midwest—not Steamboat, not Sun Valley. Hotels run $107/night. Flight to Grand Rapids is cheap from anywhere in the country. For millions of Midwesterners, it's a day trip.

◆ Final verdict

OVERALL SCORE

The part where we stop pretending this is objective.

TIER 1
Barry-Roubaix
86
/100
TIER 1 · Iconic · High Consequence

World's largest gravel race where weather roulette and Sager Road separate the prepared from the hopeful.

Course profile (Section 5) 25 / 35
Editorial profile (Section 6) 35 / 35
Final score 86 / 100

Should You Race This?

Yes, if you want the world's largest gravel race experience with unmatched value and community support. Barry-Roubaix delivers professional organization, technical challenge, and complete unpredictability. Just be ready for whatever weather Michigan throws at you and prepare for Sager Road's abuse.

Alternatives

If you want guaranteed good weather: Unbound (late May, Kansas heat). If you want smooth gravel: SBT GRVL (champagne gravel, altitude challenge). If you want less technical: Mid South (red dirt, weather lottery but less technical).

◆ THE BLACK PILL

THE THING NOBODY TELLS YOU

Barry-Roubaix's 'World's Largest' status comes with asterisks. The weather is completely unpredictable—you can train perfectly and still DNF if Michigan decides to throw 35°F windchill and snow at you. The registration sells out in 24 hours, so you can't wait to decide. And Sager Road breaks unprepared riders—both physically and mentally.

Here's what it actually costs:

  • Weather roulette means you can't know conditions until 48 hours before. Your equipment strategy, nutrition approach, and pacing all depend on a forecast that might change.
  • The registration window is brutal. If you don't sign up within 24 hours of opening, you're out. No second chances.
  • Sager Road breaks bikes. Sand ruts, mud holes, and baby-head rocks destroy equipment that isn't built for abuse.
  • The 100-mile Psycho Killer requires GPS navigation. If your device dies or you miss a turn, you're lost on an unmarked course.
  • April in Michigan means training through a Midwest winter. Most of your preparation happens indoors. The weather you train in won't match race day.

Barry-Roubaix is a fantastic race that rewards preparation and punishes assumptions. If you're ready for technical terrain, cold weather, and complete unpredictability, you'll have an unforgettable experience. Just don't expect California sunshine or smooth gravel roads.

You can train perfectly and still DNF if Michigan decides to throw 35°F windchill at you.

Race Logistics

The unsexy details that decide your day

Getting There
  • Closest major airport: Gerald R. Ford International (GRR), Grand Rapids—26 miles, 30 min drive
  • Transportation: Book immediately when registration opens—hotels fill with racers.
  • When to arrive: Plan to arrive 2-3 days early for travel, shakeout, and gear organization.
Staying There
  • Lodging: Book immediately when registration opens—hotels fill with racers. Holiday Inn Express Hastings ~$107/night. Sharp Park Campground 10% discount with code 'BarryRoubaix'. Grand Rapids hotels 30 minutes away with more availability.
  • Food & groceries: Hastings has restaurants but they're packed race weekend. Blackrocks Brewery Street Party post-race with bonfires, live music, food vendors.
  • Packet pickup: Cannonsburg Ski Area (April 12): Pre-ride, expo, $10,000+ gear giveaway. Hastings Ace Hardware (April 17): 2:00-8:00 PM. Race Morning (April 18): 5:30-9:45 AM at start line.
  • Parking: Available near start line. Arrive early for best spots.
